intro: Quercus iberica, commonly known as the Iberian oak, is a deciduous tree native to the Iberian Peninsula. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its robust, rounded canopy and deeply lobed leaves. The tree produces acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. It thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soils and is often found in mixed forests. Quercus iberica plays a vital role in maintaining biodiversity and ecological balance in its native habitat.
